sections.name: Multiple Choice Questions
sections.description: Test your analytical thinking and problem-solving skills

questions.question: If you have 5 apples and you give 2 apples to your friend, how many apples do you have left?

stepByStep: Step 2: Give away 2 apples to friend
commonMistakes: Counting the given apples as yours (answer 2)
explanation.realWorldUse: This is basic arithmetic used in everyday life - shopping, sharing items, budgeting money. In programming, we use subtraction to update quantities, calculate remaining resources, or track inventory.
keyLearnings: Subtraction operation: number1 - number2
Order matters: 5 - 2 ≠ 2 - 5
Variables can store and update values

questions.question: What comes next in this sequence? 2, 4, 6, 8, ?

stepByStep: Step 1: Look at the difference between numbers
commonMistakes: Answer 9: Just adding 1 (not noticing the +2 pattern)
Answer 12: Doubling numbers (2×6=12, but pattern is addition)
Answer 16: Doubling the last number (8×2=16, wrong operation)
explanation.realWorldUse: Pattern recognition is used in: predicting trends, understanding sequences in data, programming loops, finding bugs in repeated code, analyzing charts and graphs.
keyLearnings: Always find the pattern/rule first
Check multiple examples to confirm pattern
Arithmetic sequences: add/subtract same number
Loops in programming repeat patterns

questions.question: If today is Monday, what day will it be after 3 days?

commonMistakes: Counting Monday as day 1 instead of starting point
Skipping a day in counting (Tuesday → Thursday)
explanation.realWorldUse: Date calculations are used in: scheduling apps, calendar systems, booking systems, reminder apps, project deadlines, subscription renewals. Programs need to calculate dates correctly.
keyLearnings: Sequential counting: start point + steps
Arrays/lists store ordered items (days, months)
Modulo operator (%) wraps around (useful for repeating cycles)
Index counting often starts from 0 in programming

questions.question: You have a bag with 3 red balls and 2 blue balls. What is the total number of balls?

keyLearnings: Addition combines quantities: a + b
Variables store different types of data
Arrays/lists can hold multiple items
length/count property gives total items

questions.question: Which shape has 4 equal sides and 4 right angles?

explanation.realWorldUse: Shapes are used in: UI/UX design (buttons, icons), game development (collision detection), graphics programming, image processing, architectural design, logo design, layout grids.
keyLearnings: Geometry basics are foundation for graphics
Properties define objects (sides, angles)
Classes model real-world objects in code
Methods perform calculations (area, perimeter)

questions.question: If A is taller than B, and B is taller than C, who is the shortest?

stepByStep: Step 1: Write down what we know
Step 2: A > B (A is taller than B)
Step 3: B > C (B is taller than C)
Step 5: C is at the bottom = shortest

rows: Taller than C, shorter than A

commonMistakes: Not following the chain of logic (A→B→C)
explanation.realWorldUse: Comparisons and ordering are used in: sorting algorithms, ranking systems (scores, prices), database queries (ORDER BY), filters (show top 10), priority queues, recommendation systems.
keyLearnings: Transitive property: if A>B and B>C, then A>C
Comparison operators: >, <, >=, <=, ==
Sorting arranges items by some criteria
Logical chains help solve complex problems

Functions reuse logic for different inputs

questions.question: Which is the odd one out? Cat, Dog, Cow, Chair

Step 6: Chair is the odd one out

Not identifying the common category first

Objects map keys to values (thing → type)

questions.question: If you read 10 pages of a book every day, how many pages will you read in 3 days?

stepByStep: Step 3: Total pages = Pages per day × Days

explanation.realWorldUse: Multiplication is used in: calculating totals (price × quantity), area calculations, loops (repeat n times), scaling (2x speed), compound operations, array operations, matrix math.

Operator: a * b
Loops can accumulate values

Variables track running totals

questions.question: What is the best way to remember a friend's phone number?
options: Write it down in a notebook
Save it in your phone contacts
Ask them every time you need it

stepByStep: Step 2: Memorizing = Can forget, no backup
Step 3: Notebook = Can lose notebook, hard to search
Step 4: Phone contacts = Digital, searchable, backed up ✓
Step 5: Asking every time = Annoying, inconvenient

Objects/dictionaries map keys to values (name → phone)
Single source of truth = easier to update
Error handling (if contact not found)
Choose right storage based on needs

sections.name: Fill in the Blanks
sections.description: Complete the sentences with correct answers

explanation.whyCorrect: 5 + 3 = 8 is a basic addition operation. When you combine 5 items with 3 items, you get 8 items total.
explanation.comparisonWithAlternatives: Writing '8' (number) is correct. Writing 'eight' (word) is also acceptable. Both represent the same value. In programming, use numbers for calculations, strings for text.

questions.question: A computer program that repeats the same action multiple times uses a ___

explanation.whyCorrect: A LOOP is a programming construct that repeats a block of code multiple times. Instead of writing the same code 100 times, you write it once inside a loop and specify how many times to repeat.

comparisonWithAlternatives.forLoop: Best when you know exact number of repetitions (for i=1 to 10)
comparisonWithAlternatives.whileLoop: Best when you don't know how many times (while user hasn't quit)
comparisonWithAlternatives.doWhileLoop: Execute at least once, then check condition

bestPractices: Use for loop when count is known
Always have an exit condition (avoid infinite loops)
Keep loop body simple and focused
Use meaningful variable names (i for index, count, etc.)
commonMistakes: Infinite loop: forgetting to update counter (i++ missing)
Wrong starting value: starting from 0 vs 1
Modifying loop variable inside loop unexpectedly

questions.question: The largest ocean on Earth is the ___ Ocean

explanation.whyCorrect: The Pacific Ocean is the largest and deepest ocean on Earth, covering more than 30% of Earth's surface. It's larger than all of Earth's land area combined!
explanation.comparisonWithAlternatives: There are 5 oceans. Size comparison (million km²): Pacific (165) > Atlantic (106) > Indian (71) > Southern (20) > Arctic (14). Pacific is more than 1.5x bigger than Atlantic!
bestPractices: Use comparison operators to find max/min
commonMistakes: Lowercase 'pacific' (acceptable but proper noun should be capitalized)

questions.question: If you want to save your work on a computer before closing, you click ___

explanation.whyCorrect: 'Save' is the universal command to store your work to disk. Without saving, your work stays in RAM (temporary memory) and is lost when you close the program or computer shuts down.

comparisonWithAlternatives.SaveAs: Save with new name or location

bestPractices: Save before closing or risky operations

explanation.whyCorrect: 'Stop' is the direct opposite/antonym of 'start'. In programming and computing, start/stop are common operations for processes, services, timers, and loops.
bestPractices: Clean up resources when stopping (close files, connections)
commonMistakes: Not cleaning up on stop (memory leaks)

sections.description: Write simple code to solve problems

questions.question: Write a program to check if a number is positive, negative, or zero. The program should display an appropriate message for each case.

solution1.name: Basic Solution
solution1.explanation: This solution uses if-else-if chain to check three conditions: positive (>0), negative (<0), and zero (else). The else catches the case when number is neither positive nor negative, which means it's zero.

solution2.name: With Return Value
solution2.explanation: This version returns a string instead of printing. This is more flexible because the calling code can use the result in different ways (display, save, use in other logic).

solution3.name: Ternary Operator (Advanced)
solution3.explanation: Ternary operator (? :) is a shorthand for if-else. Format: condition ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse. Can be chained for multiple conditions. More concise but can be harder to read for beginners.

stepByStepApproach: Step 1: Create a function that takes a number as input
Step 2: Use if statement to check if number > 0 (positive case)
Step 3: Use else if to check if number < 0 (negative case)
Step 4: Use else for remaining case (zero)
Step 5: Display appropriate message or return result
Step 6: Test with positive, negative, and zero values

testCases.explanation: 5 is greater than 0, so it's positive
-3 is less than 0, so it's negative

commonMistakes.explanation: Single = assigns value, double == or triple === compares values

commonMistakes.code:
if (num < 0) negative
else if (num > 0) positive
else zero
commonMistakes.fix: Order doesn't matter here, but be consistent
commonMistakes.explanation: With separate ranges (<0, >0, =0), order doesn't matter. But with overlapping conditions, check specific cases first.

commonMistakes.fix: Always add else to handle remaining cases
commonMistakes.explanation: Without else, zero case is not handled

questions.question: Write a program to print numbers from 1 to 5 using a loop. Then modify it to print only even numbers from 2 to 10.
hints: Use a for loop to repeat
For even numbers, start from 2 and increment by 2
Or use if statement to check if number is even (num % 2 === 0)

solution1.name: Part 1: Print 1 to 5
solution1.explanation: Loop starts at i=1, continues while i<=5, increments i by 1 each time. Prints i in each iteration.

solution2.name: Part 2: Even numbers 2 to 10 (Method 1)
solution2.explanation: Start at 2 (first even), increment by 2 each time (i = i + 2 or i += 2). This directly generates even numbers, very efficient.

solution3.name: Part 2: Even numbers (Method 2 - with if)
solution3.explanation: Loop through all numbers 1-10, but only print if divisible by 2 (i % 2 === 0). Modulo operator % gives remainder: 4%2=0 (even), 5%2=1 (odd).

solution4.name: While Loop Alternative
solution4.explanation: While loop is an alternative to for loop. Remember to initialize variable before loop (i=2) and update it inside loop (i=i+2), otherwise infinite loop!

stepByStepApproach: 1. Write for loop: for (let i = 1; i <= 5; i++)
1. Loop 1 to 10: for (let i = 1; i <= 10; i++)

commonMistakes.explanation: Without incrementing i, condition i<=5 stays true forever. Infinite loop crashes browser/computer.
Even: remainder 0 when divided by 2. Odd: remainder 1.

steps: Iteration 1: i=2, Check 2<=6? YES, Print 2, Update i=2+2=4
Iteration 2: i=4, Check 4<=6? YES, Print 4, Update i=4+2=6
Iteration 3: i=6, Check 6<=6? YES, Print 6, Update i=6+2=8
Iteration 4: i=8, Check 8<=6? NO, Exit loop

sections.name: Debugging Challenge
sections.description: Find and fix errors in the given code

questions.question: The following code is supposed to add two numbers and display the result, but it has errors. Find ALL the errors and fix them.

allErrors.explanation: JavaScript keyword 'function' is misspelled as 'funtion'. This will cause 'Unexpected identifier' error. Always use correct spelling for keywords.
allErrors.howToSpot: Code editor will show red underline. Browser console shows 'Unexpected identifier' error.
allErrors.prevention: Use code editor with syntax highlighting. Pay attention to red underlines.

allErrors.error: Missing semicolon after 'let result = a + b'
allErrors.explanation: While JavaScript has Automatic Semicolon Insertion (ASI), it's best practice to always include semicolons. Can cause unexpected behavior in some cases.
allErrors.howToSpot: Linters like ESLint will warn about this. Some editors show subtle hints.
allErrors.fix: Add semicolon: let result = a + b;
allErrors.prevention: Configure editor to auto-add semicolons. Use a linter (ESLint).

allErrors.explanation: 'console' is misspelled as 'consol'. This will cause 'consol is not defined' error at runtime. 'console' is a built-in object in JavaScript for output.
allErrors.howToSpot: Browser console shows 'ReferenceError: consol is not defined'.
allErrors.prevention: Use autocomplete in editor. Type 'cons' and press Tab to auto-complete to 'console'.

allErrors.error: Missing space in string: 'The sum is' + result should have space after 'is'
allErrors.explanation: String 'The sum is' doesn't have trailing space, so output will be 'The sum is8' instead of 'The sum is 8'. Not a syntax error but produces wrong output.
allErrors.howToSpot: Test the code and look at output. Will be squished together.
allErrors.fix: Add space: 'The sum is ' + result (note space after 'is')
allErrors.prevention: Always test your output. Use template literals: `The sum is ${result}` (auto-adds space).

allErrors.explanation: Same as line 2 - missing semicolon. While code may still work due to ASI, it's not best practice.
allErrors.howToSpot: Linter will warn. Good practice to always include.

buggyCodeExecution: Line 1: Error! 'funtion' is not recognized → SyntaxError: Unexpected identifier
Code fails to run. Nothing after this line executes.
Browser console shows error and line number.
fixedCodeExecution: Line 1: function addNumbers(a, b) { → Function declared
Call: addNumbers(5, 3) → Function called with a=5, b=3
Line 3: console.log('The sum is ' + 8) → Prints 'The sum is 8'
Calling code: sum = 8 → Variable sum gets value 8

alternativeSolutions.name: Using Template Literals (Modern)
alternativeSolutions.explanation: Template literals (backticks) allow embedding variables with ${} syntax. Cleaner than string concatenation with +. Automatically handles spacing.

alternativeSolutions.name: Arrow Function (Concise)
alternativeSolutions.explanation: Arrow function is modern ES6 syntax. More concise. For simple returns, can omit braces and return keyword.

debuggingTips.explanation: Browser console shows error type, line number, and description. Read carefully!
Many errors are simple typos. Keywords like 'function', 'console', 'return' must be exact.
Add console.log() to check values: console.log('a:', a, 'b:', b, 'result:', result);
Press F12 → Console tab shows errors. Sources tab allows breakpoints and step-through debugging.
Linters catch errors as you type. Shows red underlines, suggests fixes. Install ESLint extension in VS Code.
Don't write 100 lines then test. Write a few lines, test, repeat. Easier to find bugs.
If unsure where error is, comment out code sections (//). Uncomment piece by piece to isolate bug.

instructions: MCQs have only one correct answer
Fill in the blanks with appropriate words/numbers
For programming questions, you can write code in any language or pseudocode
For debugging, identify ALL errors and explain each one
